data.name: Present Simple
rules: In the third person singular, the verb always ends in '-s'
For negative and interrogative forms, use 'does/do'
Add '-es' if verb finish with: -ss, -x, -sh, -ch
examples: I work in London
Your exam starts at 09:00
She does not run so fast
We catch the bus every morning
You walk for two hundred meters, then you turn left
New York is a large city
Water freezes at zero degrees
His mother arrives tomorrow
He goes to school every morning
She enjoys playing the piano
We do not think about that
He drinks a lot on parties
Open your books at page 34

data.name: Present Continuous
whenToUse: Actions happening at the moment of speaking
rules: Verb to be (am/are/is) + infinitive + -ing
examples: We are going to the beach
More and more people are becoming vegetarian
Are you still working for the same company?
I am not going to my home
Are you going to the office?
He usually plays the drums
He is not playing football

data.name: Present Perfect
whenToUse: When the precise time of action is not important or not know
An action or situation that started in the past and continues in the present
rules: Have/has + irregular verb: third column of irregular verbs
Have/has + regular verb: infinitive + ed
examples: I have never fallen down the stairs
I have lived in Barcelona since 1982
Have you played the piano since you were a child?
We have visited Portugal several times
We have had the same car for ten years
It has happened several times already
Someone has eaten my soup!
I've worked here for six months
I haven't gone to the cinema for a long time
I have just finished my work
He has read that book
I have just eaten
Has he just left?
I have been to London recently

data.name: Present Perfect Continuous
rules: Have/has + been + infinitive + -ing
examples: Has she been running?
Someone's been eating my chips
I've heard a lot about you recently
They have been travelling since last October
She has been cooking since last night
I have been waiting for you for three hours
He has not been playing handball
Have you been playing football?

data.name: Past Simple
rules: Regular verb: infinitive + -ed
Irregular verb: Second column of irregular verbs
Use did + infinitive verb in negative or question forms
examples: I went to school
He cleaned his room
She didn't clean the room
Did you play football?
The keys weren’t in the drawer
We didn’t believe him
I worked for many years in a museum
Did Jack win the gold medal?

data.name: Past Continuous
rules: verb to be (was, were) + infinitive + -ing
examples: I was playing with my best friend
You were not driving the car
Was he writting the letter?
He was playing the guitar
Anne was writing a letter while Steve was reading the New York Times
He was going to the mountain when he fell
He was tired because he was exercising so hard

data.name: Past Perfect
rules: Had + irregular verb: third column of irregular verbs
Had + regular verb: infinitive + ed
examples: Maria had known about it for a while

I had not eaten at that restaurant before today
Had Adam ever spoken to the CEO before he was fired?

data.name: Past Perfect Continuous
whenToUse: Action had been happening before something else happened
Emphasizes a duration of time before something in the past
rules: Had + been + infinitive + -ing
examples: We had been waiting for ages before the bus finally arrived
Betty failed the final test because she had not been attending class
She looked tired because she had been exercicing
I had been waiting for Susan for 2 hours when she arrived
How long had you been waiting to get on the bus?
James had been teaching at the university for more than a year before he left for Asia
How long had you been studying Turkish before you moved to Ankara?
You had only been waiting there for a few minutes when he arrived

data.name: Future Simple
rules: Will + verb
Be going to + verb
examples: I will help you in a few minutes

Are you going to meet Jane tonight?
Will you help me later?

data.name: Future Continuous
rules: Will be/be going to be + verb + -ing
examples: I will be waiting for her when her plane arrives tonight
Will you be waiting for her when her plane arrives tonight?

Are you going to be waiting for her when her plane arrives tonight?

data.name: Future Perfect
rules: Will/to be (am/are/is) going to + have + irregular verb: third column of irregular verbs
Will/to be (am/are/is) going to + have + regular verb: infinitive + ed
examples: She will have gone by the time he arrives
I will have written the letter by tomorrow
Will she have learned enough Chinese to communicate before she moves to Beijing?
By next November, I will have received my promotion
I am not going to have finished this test by 3 o'clock

data.name: Future Perfect Continuous
whenToUse: To show that something will continue up until a particular event or time in the future
rules: Will/to be (am/are/is) going to have been + infinitive + -ing
examples: I will have been swimming for an hour by 6:30
You will not have been waiting for more than two hours when her plane finally arrives
Are you going to have been waiting for more than two hours when her plane finally arrives?
She is going to have been working at that company for three years when it finally closes
How long will you have been studying when you graduate?
You won't get a promotion until you have been working here as long as Tim
The artist will have been painting the mural for over six months by the time it is finished
The song is going to have been being played by the musician for over seven minutes by the time it is finished
